title: Fruit growers hail reddist British apples in 20 years
text:
Apples are the most colourful they’ve been in 20 years after a perfect combination of warm days and cool nights.

The British apple harvest has reaped rosy rewards with this years pick redder than ever, according to experts.

The unusually hot days dropping into cool nights this summer have caused the apples to brighten up with trade body British Apples and Pears saying that growers are reporting the most colourful crop they’ve seen since the millenium.

In order to achieve a vibrant red there needs to be a difference of at least 10 degrees between day and night, ideally reaching 15 degrees difference.

Ali Capper, Chief Executive British Apples & Pears said: “The consumer loves a red rosy apple.

“That red colour comes through the differential of the day and nighttime temperature.

“Scientists tell me that it’s at least 10 degrees difference but I would say it’s at least 15 - that is when you really start to see things move and literally the apples will change colour in front of your eyes.”

Ms Capper added: “The middle of August all the way through to most of September we’ve have nice warm days and cool nights getting down to five or six degrees.
